bestBHT.bht: In this scene of judgment, Jesus separates the sheep and goats, placing the sheep on his right hand, a position of honor, and the goats on his left, symbolizing dishonor. The sheep, representing the righteous, are compared to innocence and harmlessness, while the goats signify the wicked. This separation illustrates the division between believers and non-believers, echoing the parables of the Tares and the Net. The Greek reader is presented with a vivid image of a row starting at the judge's right hand. What is evident is that one's faith and actions significantly impact their eternal destiny.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 33. And he shall set the sheep on
his right hand—the side of honor (1 Kings 2:19;
but the goats on the left—the
Albert Barnes: By 'the sheep' are denoted, here, the righteous. The name is given to them because the sheep is an emblem of innocence and harmlessness.
The right hand is the place of honor, and denotes the situation of those who are honored, or those who are virtuous.
The goats - The wicked. See Ezekiel 34:17.
Marvin Vincent: The sheep and goats are represented as having previously pastured together. Compare the parables of the Tares and the Net.
On the right [εκ δεξιων] . Lit., from the right side or parts. The picture to the Greek reader is that of a row, beginning at the judge 's right hand.
Philip Schaff: The sheep on his right hand, the place of preference.
The pre-millenial view refers ‘the sheep’ to the unconscious Christians among the heathen.
But how unlikely that, in this great picture, believers should be excluded, when the term ‘sheep’ is appropriated to them so often.
John Gill: The sheep the Father gave unto Christ, and made his care and charge, whom he, as the good shepherd, laid down his life for.
These Christ will set on his right hand, as a token of his affection for them, and a mark of respect and honour shown them.
These he will place at his left hand, in token of his disaffection for them, as a brand of disgrace upon them, and as an intimation of that dishonour, and miserable condition they will quickly be in.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 25:33, Jesus separates the sheep and the goats, placing the sheep on his right hand, a position of honor, and the goats on his left, a position of dishonor. The sheep are seen as innocent and harmless, representing the righteous, while the goats symbolize the wicked. The distinction between the two groups reminds us of the parables of the Tares and the Net, highlighting the separation of believers and non-believers. This portrayal of the judgment is a powerful image for the Greek reader, as it depicts a row beginning at the judge’s right hand. Ultimately, this verse underscores the importance of one's faith and actions in determining their eternal destiny.

In this depiction of judgment, Jesus separates the sheep and goats, placing the sheep on his right hand, a position of honor, and the goats on his left, a position of dishonor. The sheep represent the innocent and righteous, while the goats symbolize the wicked. This portrayal emphasizes the separation between believers and non-believers, as shown in the parables of the Tares and the Net. The Greek reader would understand the imagery of a row starting at the judge's right hand. This verse underscores the significance of faith and deeds in determining one's eternal destiny.

Jesus, in Matthew 25:33, distinguishes the sheep and goats, positioning the sheep on his right hand, denoting honor, and the goats on his left, implying dishonor. The sheep symbolize the righteous, likened to innocence and harmlessness, while the goats represent the wicked. This separation parallels the parables of the Tares and the Net, emphasizing the division between believers and non-believers. To the Greek reader, this imagery signifies a line beginning at the judge's right hand. This verse serves as a reminder of the essential role faith and actions play in determining one's eternal fate.

In this scene of judgment, Jesus separates the sheep and goats, placing the sheep on his right hand, a position of honor, and the goats on his left, symbolizing dishonor. The sheep, representing the righteous, are compared to innocence and harmlessness, while the goats signify the wicked. This separation illustrates the division between believers and non-believers, echoing the parables of the Tares and the Net. The Greek reader is presented with a vivid image of a row starting at the judge's right hand. What is evident is that one's faith and actions significantly impact their eternal destiny.

In this portrayal of judgment, Jesus distinguishes between the sheep and the goats, positioning the sheep on his right hand as a mark of honor, and placing the goats on his left as a sign of dishonor. The sheep symbolize the righteous, characterized by innocence and harmlessness, while the goats represent the wicked. This separation parallels the idea of believers and non-believers brought forth in the parables of the Tares and the Net. The Greek reader would understand this as a row starting from the judge's right hand. Overall, this verse emphasizes the significance of faith and actions in shaping one's eternal destiny.
